definitions: provide the body with water to maintain proper fluid levels and function
cause a substance to chemically combine with water molecules
examples: Athletes need to hydrate before and after intense workouts
She hydrates her skin daily with a moisturizing cream
The powder will hydrate when mixed with warm water
Scientists hydrate the crystals to study their molecular structure

definitions: travel quickly across the surface of water in a motorboat or aircraft
slide uncontrollably on a wet road surface when a layer of water prevents direct contact between tires and road
examples: The speedboat began to hydroplane across the lake surface
Small aircraft can hydroplane during water landings
My car started to hydroplane on the flooded highway
Drivers should slow down to avoid hydroplaning in heavy rain

definitions: sing songs of worship or praise typically in religious settings
express devotion or celebration through melodic verses often about spiritual themes
examples: The congregation hymned together during Sunday morning service
Children hymned Christmas carols at the church pageant
The poets hymned nature's beauty in their verses
Ancient Greeks hymned their gods during sacred festivals

definitions: promote or publicize something intensively often with exaggerated claims or excitement
generate excessive or aggressive publicity to create anticipation or interest
examples: The company hyped their new product for months before launch
Musicians often hype their albums on social media platforms
Don't believe everything they hype in the advertisements
The media hyped the event beyond its actual significance

definitions: connect words or parts of words using a short horizontal line mark
examples: You should hyphen compound adjectives like well-known
The editor asked me to hyphen the phrase twenty-one
Writers hyphen words at line breaks to maintain text flow
Always hyphen prefixes when they precede proper nouns

definitions: induce a trance-like state in someone through focused attention and suggestion
capture someone's complete attention making them unable to look away or think of anything else
examples: The therapist will hypnotize patients to help them quit smoking
Stage performers hypnotize volunteers from the audience for entertainment
The snake's movements seemed to hypnotize the small bird
Her beautiful voice could hypnotize listeners for hours

definitions: suggest an explanation for something that can be tested through research or experimentation
form a tentative assumption based on limited evidence as a starting point for investigation
examples: Scientists hypothesize about the causes of climate change
Researchers hypothesize that exercise improves mental health
Detectives hypothesize different scenarios to solve the case
Students learn to hypothesize before conducting science experiments

definitions: run an engine slowly while the vehicle remains stationary and not engaged in gear
spend time doing nothing productive or avoiding activity when work is available
examples: Let the car idle for a minute before driving off
The engine idles smoothly after the recent tune-up
Workers idle by the water cooler instead of finishing tasks
Don't idle away your summer vacation watching television

definitions: cause something to catch fire or start burning through heat or spark
trigger or spark intense feelings passion or conflict in people
examples: Use a match to ignite the campfire kindling
The spark plug ignites fuel in the engine cylinder
Her speech ignited passion in the hearts of listeners
The controversial decision ignited protests across the country

definitions: provide light to a space or object making it visible or bright
clarify or explain something making it easier to understand through examples or explanation
examples: Street lamps illuminate the sidewalk for evening joggers
Candles illuminate the dining room during the power outage
The professor's examples illuminate complex mathematical concepts
Historical documents illuminate how people lived centuries ago

definitions: inspire or permeate with a feeling quality or emotion throughout something
soak or saturate something thoroughly with a liquid or moisture
examples: Great teachers imbue their students with curiosity and wonder
The artist imbued her paintings with deep emotional meaning
The chef imbued the meat with aromatic herbs and spices
Rain imbued the dry soil with much-needed moisture

definitions: copy the way someone speaks moves or behaves often to entertain or learn
reproduce or copy something to look like the original
examples: Children often imitate their parents' mannerisms and speech patterns
The comedian could imitate famous politicians perfectly
Artists learn by trying to imitate masterpiece paintings
Cheap products often imitate expensive designer brands

definitions: dip or submerge something or someone completely in liquid
involve oneself deeply in a particular activity subject or interest
examples: Immerse the vegetables in boiling water for two minutes
The priest will immerse believers during the baptism ceremony
Students immerse themselves in language study abroad programs
She likes to immerse herself in a good book

definitions: come to live permanently in a foreign country leaving one's native land
examples: My grandparents immigrated from Italy in the 1920s
Many people immigrate to find better job opportunities
Skilled workers often immigrate through special visa programs
The family decided to immigrate after receiving refugee status

definitions: prevent something or someone from moving or operating normally through restraint or damage
make someone unable to act or respond effectively in a situation
examples: The doctor will immobilize your broken arm with a cast
Heavy snow can immobilize traffic for hours
Fear can immobilize people in dangerous situations
The unexpected news seemed to immobilize the entire team

definitions: weaken or damage something especially regarding its normal functioning or quality
examples: Loud noise can impair your hearing over time
Alcohol consumption will impair your ability to drive safely
The injury may impair his athletic performance permanently
Lack of sleep can impair judgment and decision-making

definitions: pass on or communicate information knowledge or skills to someone
give a particular quality characteristic or flavor to something
examples: Teachers impart wisdom to their students every day
Parents impart important values to their children
Herbs impart flavor to the soup
The wood finish imparts a warm glow to the furniture

definitions: charge a public official formally with misconduct while in office
call into question the credibility or validity of something or someone
examples: Congress voted to impeach the president for abuse of power
The committee may impeach judges who violate ethical standards
The lawyer tried to impeach the witness's testimony
New evidence could impeach the study's conclusions

definitions: delay or prevent someone or something from moving or progressing normally
examples: Heavy traffic will impede our journey to the airport
Bureaucratic rules often impede business innovation
Don't let fear impede your personal growth
The fallen tree impeded access to the hiking trail

definitions: pretend to be another person for entertainment deception or fraud
examples: The actor could impersonate the president remarkably well
It's illegal to impersonate a police officer
Comedians often impersonate celebrities in their routines
The criminal tried to impersonate a bank employee

definitions: surgically place a device or tissue into someone's body for medical purposes
fix an idea belief or attitude firmly in someone's mind
examples: Surgeons will implant a pacemaker to regulate his heartbeat
Dentists implant artificial teeth to replace missing ones
The coach tried to implant confidence in the young players
Early experiences implant lasting memories in children's minds

definitions: show or suggest that someone is involved in a crime or wrongdoing
indicate that something is involved in or connected to something else
examples: The evidence implicates him in the robbery
Don't implicate innocent people in your schemes
Studies implicate processed foods in various health problems
The report implicates poor management in the company's failure

definitions: legally seize and hold property vehicles or animals in official custody
examples: Police will impound vehicles parked in tow-away zones
Authorities impound dangerous dogs until hearings are held
Customs agents impound illegal goods at the border
The city may impound your car for unpaid tickets

definitions: transfer computer files between systems over a network using file transfer protocol
examples: You can ftp large files to the server overnight
Web developers ftp website updates to hosting servers
Students ftp their assignments to the professor's directory
The company uses secure channels to ftp sensitive data

definitions: press or stamp a mark or design onto a surface leaving an impression
fix an image or memory permanently in someone's mind through strong impression
examples: The machine will imprint your name on the leather wallet
Birds imprint their footprints in the wet sand
Traumatic events often imprint themselves on our memories
Baby animals imprint on the first creature they see

definitions: put someone in prison as punishment for a crime
confine or trap someone in a place or situation they cannot escape
examples: The judge will imprison him for ten years
The state can imprison people who commit serious crimes
Don't let fear imprison you in your comfort zone
The avalanche imprisoned hikers in the mountain cabin

definitions: create and perform music drama or speech spontaneously without preparation
make or provide something using whatever materials or resources are available
examples: Jazz musicians often improvise during live performances
The actor had to improvise when he forgot his lines
We had to improvise a shelter from branches and leaves
Good cooks can improvise meals with leftover ingredients

definitions: make something inactive unable to function or no longer effective
examples: High temperatures inactivate many harmful bacteria
The technician will inactivate your old security badge
Certain chemicals can inactivate dangerous viruses
You can inactivate the alarm by entering the code

definitions: mark the beginning of an institution activity or period in a formal way
admit someone formally to public office in a special ceremony
examples: The university will inaugurate its new science building next month
The festival inaugurates the summer concert season
The nation will inaugurate its new president in January
The ceremony will inaugurate the newly elected mayor

definitions: prevent someone from functioning normally or at full capacity through injury illness or other means
examples: The accident incapacitated him for several months
A severe migraine can incapacitate someone for hours
The virus incapacitated half the workforce last winter
One faulty component can incapacitate the entire system

definitions: embody a deity spirit or quality in flesh or physical form
represent an abstract quality or idea in human or physical form
examples: Many religions believe gods incarnate as humans
The story tells how spirits incarnate in different forms
She seems to incarnate grace and elegance
The villain incarnates pure evil in the story

definitions: make someone extremely angry or enraged by something unfair or offensive
examples: The unfair decision incensed the entire community
His rude comments incensed everyone at the meeting
Don't incense your boss by arriving late again
The new policy incensed workers who felt betrayed

definitions: encourage or stir up violent or unlawful behavior in others
examples: The speaker's words incited the crowd to riot
Social media posts can incite violence if not monitored
Leaders who incite hatred face criminal charges
Don't incite panic by spreading false rumors

definitions: lean or turn away from a vertical or horizontal position
have a tendency or preference toward a particular opinion or action
examples: Incline your head forward during the neck exercise
The path inclines steeply as it approaches the summit
I incline toward accepting their job offer
Most voters incline to support environmental protection

definitions: cause trouble difficulty or discomfort to someone by disrupting their plans or routine
examples: We apologize if the construction noise inconveniences you
Don't inconvenience others with your personal problems
The delayed flight will inconvenience hundreds of passengers
I don't want to inconvenience you during dinner

definitions: make someone appear guilty of a crime or wrongdoing by providing evidence
examples: The fingerprints incriminate him in the burglary
Don't say anything that might incriminate you
The leaked documents incriminate several government officials
The witness refused to incriminate her friends

definitions: sit on eggs or keep them warm so they will hatch
develop slowly without obvious signs before emerging or becoming apparent
examples: Birds incubate their eggs for several weeks
The laboratory incubates bacteria samples at body temperature
Ideas often incubate in the subconscious before emerging
The disease can incubate for months without symptoms

definitions: teach or impress an idea or principle on someone through persistent instruction or repetition
examples: Parents inculcate good manners in their children
Schools inculcate civic values through daily activities
Military training inculcates discipline and teamwork
The program aims to inculcate healthy eating habits

definitions: become subject to something unwelcome or harmful as a result of one's actions
examples: You will incur additional fees for late payment
Reckless driving can incur serious legal penalties
The company incurred massive debts during expansion
Don't incur unnecessary expenses during the recession

definitions: bind someone by a formal contract especially for apprenticeship or labor
examples: Employers would indenture workers for specific time periods
Colonial Americans would indenture servants for passage overseas
The agreement will indenture apprentices to master craftsmen
Historical documents show how companies indentured laborers

definitions: formally charge or accuse someone of a serious crime based on evidence
examples: The grand jury voted to indict him for fraud
Prosecutors will indict several executives next week
The evidence is sufficient to indict on multiple counts
Federal authorities indict suspects in the corruption case

definitions: allow oneself to enjoy the pleasure of something especially something considered unnecessary
satisfy or give way to a desire wish or whim without restraint
examples: I occasionally indulge in expensive chocolate
Parents shouldn't indulge every whim of their children
She likes to indulge in a spa day once a month
Don't indulge in self-pity when things go wrong

definitions: contaminate a person animal or plant with a disease-causing organism
affect with a negative or harmful quality or influence that spreads
examples: The virus can infect anyone who isn't vaccinated
One sick worker could infect the entire office
Negative attitudes can infect team morale quickly
Don't let pessimism infect your outlook on life

definitions: deduce or conclude information from evidence and reasoning rather than explicit statements
examples: Scientists infer climate patterns from ice core samples
Readers must infer the character's motivation from actions
We can infer from the data that sales are declining
Don't infer meaning that isn't actually there

definitions: be present in large numbers typically causing damage or disease
examples: Termites infest the old wooden structure
Weeds infest the garden if not controlled regularly
Rats infest abandoned buildings in the city
Parasites can infest both humans and animals

definitions: enter or gain access to an organization or place secretly especially to acquire information
pass into or through something by filtering or permeating gradually
examples: Spies infiltrate enemy organizations to gather intelligence
Protesters tried to infiltrate the private meeting
Water can infiltrate through tiny cracks in the foundation
The new ideas slowly infiltrate mainstream thinking

definitions: fill something with air or gas so it becomes enlarged
increase something by an excessive or unrealistic amount especially prices or numbers
examples: Use this pump to inflate your bicycle tires
The balloon artist inflates dozens of balloons daily
Companies sometimes inflate their profits in reports
Don't inflate your accomplishments on your resume

definitions: cause something unpleasant or painful to be suffered by someone or something
examples: The storm inflicted severe damage on coastal towns
Don't inflict your bad mood on everyone else
The injury inflicted permanent damage to his knee
Wars inflict terrible suffering on civilian populations

definitions: actively break the terms of a law agreement or someone's rights
examples: Copying this software would infringe copyright laws
The new regulations infringe on personal freedoms
Don't infringe on your neighbor's property
Companies that infringe patents face legal action

definitions: fill someone or something with an emotion or quality throughout
soak tea leaves or herbs in liquid to extract flavor or healing properties
examples: The coach tried to infuse confidence into the team
Her paintings infuse ordinary scenes with magical beauty
Infuse the herbs in hot water for ten minutes
The chef will infuse oil with garlic and rosemary
